body:
1) Load the framework files directly from our our CDN:

title: Select2
intro: Select2 is a jQuery based replacement for select boxes. It supports searching, remote data sets, and infinite scrolling of results.
markup:
<select class="select2 form-control" multiple="multiple" data-placeholder="Select one or more months" data-allow-clear="true">
    <option value="JAN">January</option>
    <option value="FEB">February</option>
    <option value="MAR">March</option>
    <option value="APR">April</option>
    <option value="MAY">May</option>
    <option value="JUN">June</option>
    <option value="JUL">July</option>
    <option value="AUG">August</option>
    <option value="SEP">September</option>
    <option value="OCT">October</option>
    <option value="NOV">November</option>
    <option value="DEC">December</option>
</select>

<hr>

<select class="select2 form-control" data-placeholder="Select one" data-allow-clear="true">
    <option value="JAN">January</option>
    <option value="FEB">February</option>
    <option value="MAR">March</option>
    <option value="APR">April</option>
    <option value="MAY">May</option>
    <option value="JUN">June</option>
    <option value="JUL">July</option>
    <option value="AUG">August</option>
    <option value="SEP">September</option>
    <option value="OCT">October</option>
    <option value="NOV">November</option>
    <option value="DEC">December</option>
</select>

<hr>

<select class="select2 form-control" multiple="multiple" data-placeholder="Select one or more months" data-allow-clear="true" data-source="/api/staff/1000">

title: Alerts
intro: Inform your users about relevant and timely events.
markup:
Inline Alerts

Success Success messages should be displayed after user successfully performs an operation.
By that I mean a complete operation – no partial operations and no errors.
Info The purpose of information messages is to inform the user about something relevant.
Warning Warning messages should be displayed to a user when an operation couldn't be completed in a whole.
Error Error messages should be displayed when an operation couldn't be completed at all.

Pop-up Alerts

best_practices:
• Use when you have a large set of items to show, but want to let the user concentrate his or her attention only on a select few items at a time
  • Use when you want to tease the user by letting him or her know that there are more items available than what is currently shown.
  • Use when you do not have enough space to show all items at once.
avoid:
• Do not use when the items are non-visual such as links to text articles, PDF documents etc.
  • Do not use when the content linked to cannot be immediately identified by an image.

title: WYSIWYG
intro: Super simple WYSIWYG editor.
markup: <textarea class="form-control summernote"></textarea>
best_practices:
• Use when you want to give the user a clear indication of what their content will look like when it is published. 
  • Use when the users of a site are not comfortable with formatting text using HTML codes or a markup language such as textile or markdown.
  • Use to lower the barrier of letting your users add formatted content to your site.
  • Use when you want an easy way to integrate media into the formatted content of your site that does not require HTML or any other syntax knowledge.
  • Use when the user is inclined to spend time correcting small details on their content. WYSIWYG allows users to see formatted results as they edit, this increases their confidence and allows for quick and good looking results.
avoid:
• Do not use if you want to keep the HTML syntax clean. Many WYSIWYG editors are known to produce bloated and untidy HTML code.
  • Do not use if you want the editor to function in all browsers. WYSIWYG editors rarely support all browsers, and if they do, it is often only the latest releases of the browsers.

title: Wizard
intro: Divides a complex goal into multiple steps by separating sub-tasks or content into panes.
body: If you're using a form with Wizard, make sure to include the data-parsley-group="blockX" where X matches the closest data-step attribute (container div). That way, the framework can match the form step with the fields include within and perform validation accordingly.
markup:
• 1One
  • 2Two
  • 3Three

Step One

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. Quisquam illo iure aperiam minima amet voluptates, quia nostrum. Doloribus iste, modi explicabo sed non. Necessitatibus id ab quaerat temporibus delectus laborum!

Step Two

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. Quisquam illo iure aperiam minima amet voluptates, quia nostrum. Doloribus iste, modi explicabo sed non. Necessitatibus id ab quaerat temporibus delectus laborum!

Step Three

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. Quisquam illo iure aperiam minima amet voluptates, quia nostrum. Doloribus iste, modi explicabo sed non. Necessitatibus id ab quaerat temporibus delectus laborum!
best_practices:
• Use when the user needs to perform a task or a goal that dictates more than one step.
    • An example is adding an image to a website which can include uploading the image and cropping the image; the image cannot be cropped before it is uploaded to a server.
  • Use when the user needs to perform a complex task consisting of several dependable sub-tasks.
  • Use when the user needs to input complex data into a system but the tasks is more easily achieved by splitting the process into a series of smaller and simpler steps.
  • Use when the user needs guidance: the user wants to achieve an overall goal, but may not be familiar in the steps needed to reach the goal.
  • Use when the steps needed to reach a final goal may vary due to decisions made in previous stages.
  • Use when the user lacks necessary domain knowledge.
  • Use when the user must complete steps in a specific sequence.

title: Tabs
intro: Generate a tabbed interface.
markup:
• Tab One
  • Tab Two
  • Tab Three
  • Tab Four
Tab One
Tab Two
Tab Thee
Tab Four
best_practices:
• Use when there are between 2 – 9 sections of content that need a flat navigation mode.
  • Use when section names are relatively short
  • Use when you want the navigation to fill the entire width of a page
  • Use when you want to provide a list of the highest available sections/subsections of the website
avoid:
• Do not use when wanting to show content-specific data. For instance for showing latest articles
  • Do not use when there is no need to single-out the currently selected option
  • Do not use when the list of sections or categories call for a “more…” link. Then consider another navigation pattern.

title: Gallery
best_practices:
• Use when the user needs to browse through a series of images in a sequential way.
  • Use to enforce a sense of beginning and end.
  • Use when the user would like as much screen real estate as possible reserved for displaying images in high resolution.
avoid: • Do not use when the purpose is to give the user a quick overview of multiple images at one time

title: Breadcrumb
intro: Responsive breadcrumbs
body: Breadcrumbs serve as an effective visual aid, indicating the location of the user within the app hierarchy, making them a great source of contextual information for landing pages / sections within the app. Also, breadcrumbs allow for easy navigation to higher-level pages.
markup:
1. Home
  2. Getting Started
  3. Library
  4. Document
  5. Components
  6. JavaScript
  7. Customize
  8. Data
best_practices:
• Use when the structure of the application follows a strict hierarchical structure of similar formatted content.
  • Use when the structure of the site is partitioned in to sections which can be divided into more subsections and so on.
  • Use when the user is most likely to have landed on the page from an external source (another site deep linking to the web page in question). 
  • Use when the page in question is placed fairly deep into the hierarchy of pages and when no other form of visual navigation can show the details of the same deep level.
  • Use together with some sort of main navigation.
avoid:
• Do not use on the topmost level of the hierarchy (typically the welcome page)
  • Do not use alone as the main navigation of the website.

best_practices:
• Use A-Z lists when users know the name of the thing they want;
  • Only use this for very long lists (100 items or more);

title: Breadcrumb
intro: Responsive breadcrumbs
markup:
1. Home
  2. Getting Started
  3. Library
  4. Document
  5. Components
  6. JavaScript
  7. Customize
  8. Data
best_practices:
• Use when the structure of the application follows a strict hierarchical structure of similar formatted content.
  • Use when the structure of the site is partitioned in to sections which can be divided into more subsections and so on.
  • Use when the user is most likely to have landed on the page from an external source (another site deep linking to the web page in question). 
  • Use when the page in question is placed fairly deep into the hierarchy of pages and when no other form of visual navigation can show the details of the same deep level.
  • Use together with some sort of main navigation.
avoid:
• Do not use on the topmost level of the hierarchy (typically the welcome page)
  • Do not use alone as the main navigation of the website.

title: Gallery
best_practices:
• Use when the user needs to browse through a series of images in a sequential way.
  • Use to enforce a sense of beginning and end.
  • Use when the user would like as much screen real estate as possible reserved for displaying images in high resolution.
avoid: • Do not use when the purpose is to give the user a quick overview of multiple images at one time

title: Tabs
intro: Generate a tabbed interface.
markup:
• Tab One
  • Tab Two
  • Tab Three
  • Tab Four
Tab One
Tab Two
Tab Thee
Tab Four
best_practices:
• Use when there are between 2 – 9 sections of content that need a flat navigation mode.
  • Use when section names are relatively short
  • Use when you want the navigation to fill the entire width of a page
  • Use when you want to provide a list of the highest available sections/subsections of the website
avoid:
• Do not use when wanting to show content-specific data. For instance for showing latest articles
  • Do not use when there is no need to single-out the currently selected option
  • Do not use when the list of sections or categories call for a “more…” link. Then consider another navigation pattern.

title: WYSIWYG
intro: Super simple WYSIWYG editor
markup: <textarea class="form-control summernote"></textarea>
best_practices:
• Use when you want to give the user a clear indication of what their content will look like when it is published. 
  • Use when the users of a site are not comfortable with formatting text using HTML codes or a markup language such as textile or markdown.
  • Use to lower the barrier of letting your users add formatted content to your site.
  • Use when you want an easy way to integrate media into the formatted content of your site that does not require HTML or any other syntax knowledge.
  • Use when the user is inclined to spend time correcting small details on their content. WYSIWYG allows users to see formatted results as they edit, this increases their confidence and allows for quick and good looking results.
avoid:
• Do not use if you want to keep the HTML syntax clean. Many WYSIWYG editors are known to produce bloated and untidy HTML code.
  • Do not use if you want the editor to function in all browsers. WYSIWYG editors rarely support all browsers, and if they do, it is often only the latest releases of the browsers.

body: Introduces a mode in which users cannot interact with your application until the mode is closed. Interrupt the user’s attention and halt all other actions until a message is dealt with or dismissed.

resources: 5 Essential UX Rules for Dialog Design

title: Loss Aversion
intro: Our fear of losing motivates us more than the prospect of gaining something of equal value

title: Blank Slate Page
intro: Comfort, guide, or encourage users when there is no content to show.
body: The blank slate is generally the first screen the user is presented with when they start something new in an application. It can the screen they are directed to after creating an account or the first screen they see when using part of an application they haven’t used before. The blank slate tells the user what the page they are on will look like, once it has eventually been filled with content. Creating a blank slate sets the user’s expectations for your service.

best_practices:
• Use when your application feels without life and empty before the user has started to enter data into the system. 
  • Use when you want to motivate the user to start using the system. 
  • Use when you want to aid the user in getting started with your web application. 
  • Use when you want to show best practices of using your web application. Use when you want to guide the user to get a good start with your web application.

title: Status-Quo Bias
intro: We tend to accept the default option instead of comparing the actual benefit to the actual cost

title: Dashboard Widgets
intro: Provide real-time insight into the current state of the most important metrics of a system.
body: Dashboards enable users to make instantaneous and informed decisions at a glance by letting them monitor the major functions of a system efficiently. They indicate what items require urgent attention at the top and move less critical statistics to the bottom. A good dashboard is simple, communicates well, has a minimum of distractions, tries not to confuse, and presents information visually so it is easily perceived.

title: Optimism Bias
intro: We consistently overstate expected success and downplay expected failure

title: Framing
intro: We tend to avoid risk when a positive frame is presented but seek risks when a negative frame is presented

title: Endowment Effect
intro: We place greater value on objects we own over objects we do not, especially if sentimental value has been placed in them

title: Negativity bias
intro: We have a tendency to pay more attention and give more weight to negative than positive experiences or other kinds of information.

title: Illusion of control
intro: We have a tendency to believe that outcomes can be controlled, or at least influenced, when they clearly cannot.

title: Need for closure
intro: We have a desire for definite cognitive closure as opposed to enduring ambiguity.

title: Value attribution
intro: We tend to attribute the value, goodness, or authenticity of something to its context instead of the thing itself

title: Search
markup:
Filter Results: (123)

Georgraphy

  • and more...

title: Limited duration
intro: Use time limitations to push users to take action

title: Intentional gaps
intro: Create intentional gaps that users can't help but try to fill

title: Curiosity
intro: We crave more when teased with a small bit of interesting information

title: Scarcity
intro: If something is promoted as being scarce, we perceive it as more desirable and more valuable

title: Set Completion
intro: We desire collecting all pieces of a set more the closer it is to being complete

title: Appropriate challenge
intro: The user needs appropriate challenges to remain engaged

title: Peak-end rule
intro: We primarily judge past experiences on how they were at their peak and how they ended

title: Storytelling
intro: Use the narrative qualities of storytelling to let the user engage in a perspective

title: Fixed rewards
intro: Use rewards to encourage continuation or introduction of wanted behavior

title: Levels
intro: Use levels to communicate progress and gauge users’ personal development

title: Variable rewards
intro: Use random rewards to convey a sense of scarcity and unpredictability to entice users curiosity in discovering the pattern

title: Completion
intro: Provide a feeling of closure by rewarding users at the completion of a goal

title: Prolonged play
intro: Reward users by prolonging their game time to allow for higher scores and measures of success

title: Powers
intro: Give users a way to reach their goal more quickly than they could before.

title: Praise
intro: Use explicit statements, graphics, a sound effect, or similar indicator to reward a job well done.

title: Limited choice
intro: We are more likely to make a decision when there are fewer options to choose from

title: Achievements
intro: We are engaged by activities in which meaningful achievements are recognized

title: Unlock features
intro: Utilize a user’s desire to explore by unlocking new features as a reward for specific behaviors

title: Tunnelling
intro: Guiding users through a process or experience provides opportunities to persuade along the way

title: Reduction
intro: Reduce complex behavior to simple tasks, increasing the benefit/cost ratio and in turn influencing users to perform

title: Chunking
intro: Information grouped into familiar, manageable units is more easily processed and remembered

title: Sequencing
intro: It is easier to take action when complex activities are broken down into smaller and more manageable tasks

title: Isolation Effect
intro: Items that stand out from their peers are more memorable

title: Recognition over recall
intro: We are better at recognizing things previously experienced than we are at recalling them from memory

title: Pattern recognition
intro: Even when there is no pattern, we seek ways to organize and simplify complex information

title: Anchoring
intro: When making decisions, we rely, or anchor, too heavily on one piece of information

title: Conceptual metaphor
intro: We understand a new idea or concept by linking it to another

title: Serial Positioning Effect
intro: We have a tendency to recall the first and the last items in a series best

title: Feedback loops
intro: Communicate how our actions modify subsequent results

title: Trigger
intro: Use small nudges to cue users to take action – directly or through learned associations

title: Kairos
intro: Communicate to users in situations that are the opportune moments for change

title: Simulation
intro: Let users play with and learn your system without the fear of messing up

title: Liking
intro: We prefer to say yes to the requests of someone we know and like

title: Delighters
intro: We remember and respond favorably to new, unexpected, and playful pleasures

title: Reputation
intro: We adjust our personal behavior to reflect positively on how peers or the public perceive us

title: Status
intro: We constantly assess our social or professional standing relative to others, seeing how interactions either enhance or diminish it

title: Commitment & consistency
intro: We want to appear consistent with our stated beliefs and prior actions and also value this quality in others

title: Authority
intro: We have a strong tendency to comply with authority figures

title: Positive mimicry
intro: We learn by comparing our behavior with the actions of others

title: Nostalgia Effect
intro: Reminiscing about the past make us downplay costs

title: Reciprocation
intro: We feel obliged to give when we receive

title: Role playing
intro: People act according to their persona

title: Competition
intro: When sharing the same environment, we'll strive to attain things that cannot be shared

title: Social proof
intro: We assume the actions of others in new or unfamiliar situations

title: Revenge
intro: People repay in kind

title: Self-Expression
intro: People seek opportunities to add a personal touch, resulting in deeper and longer engagements

title: Grid
intro: Leverages Bootstrap to includes a powerful mobile-first flexbox grid system for building layouts of all shapes and sizes.
